1946-2017
PR 368Collection processed by Ariana Heinsdorf and Larry WeimerNew-York Historical SocietyNew-York Historical Society170 Central Park WestNew York, NY 10024 (212) 873-3400This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2018-11-30T22:25:35Finding aid written in EnglishDescribing Archives: A Content Standard
New-York Historical Society
Park West Camera Club records
Park West Camera Club (New York, N.Y.)
PR 368
11.3 Linear feet in 3 document boxes, one flat box, and 11 flat files.
1946-2017 The Park West Camera Club records include newsletters (primarily 1984-2014), meeting minutes (primarily 1947-1959 and some from the late 1970s and early 1980s), and original member photography, among other documents. The club was founded in 1937 as an educational offering of the New York City YMCA's 63rd Street branch, and the organization continues, though now independent of the YMCA. Original photographs in the collection range from the 1940s into the early 2000s.
Scope and Contents
The collection includes newsletters and administrative records of the Park West Camera Club (PWCC), and examples of the photographs taken by its members. The records are not complete, but do hold substantial runs of important documents. The newsletters date primarily from 1984 to 2014. Minutes of meetings are primarily from 1947-1959, with some from the late 1970s and early 1980s. Some of the club's group activities are documented, most notably its 2015 exhibition Through Our Eyes and the 2017 exhibition celebrating PWCC's 80th anniversary. Original photographic prints by members comprise a significant part of the collection. These photographs range in date from the 1940s to the early 2000s.
Arrangement
The collection is organized in four series:
Series I. Newsletters (1984-2014)
Series II. Administrative Files (1946-1959, 1978-2017)
Series III. Club Activities and Exhibitions (1947-2017)
Series IV. Photography by Members (1940s-2000s)
Biographical / Historical
The Park West Camera Club was founded in 1937. Originally called the Hypo Hounds, the club began as an educational offering of the 63rd Street branch of the YMCA in New York City. The group changed its name to Park West Camera Club in 1952. It remained affiliated with the YMCA for several decades, until the 1990s or early 2000s. At the YMCA the group had a basement meeting space with equipment for developing photographs. This space was also used to house the organization's records and select member photography. In the 1990s, the basement space flooded, destroying many records and photographs, and damaging others. The incident spurred the creation of an Archives Committee led by Myrna Harrison-Changar, which eventually drew on the salvaged material to mount the exhibition Eight Decades of Photography in 2017 in celebration of PWCC's 80th anniversary. The exhibition was held at the Soho Gallery in Tribeca, where PWCC had taken up residence after it spun off from its YMCA affiliation. As of 2018, PWCC still meets weekly at the Gallery.
(The above note was based on information from the collection and from PWCC's website.)
Conditions Governing Access
Open to qualified researchers by appointment only.
Conditions Governing Use
Permission to reproduce any Print Room holdings through publication must be obtained from: Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 270. Fax: (212) 579-8794
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Gift of the Park West Camera Club, 2018.
Preferred Citation
This collection should be cited as: Park West Camera Club records, PR 368, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.
Processing Information
The collection was processed by archivist Larry Weimer and archival intern Ariana Heinsdorf in 2018.
Clubs -- New York (State) -- New York. Photographers -- New York (State) -- New York. Minutes (administrative records) Newsletters. Photographs. Park West Camera Club (New York, N.Y.) -- Archives
Series I. Newsletters.5 Linear feetin one box1984-2014
Scope and Contents
This series contains newsletters and documents that were sent out with newsletters from 1984-2014. These years seem to be complete, although there may be a few issues unaccounted for. Some newsletters from before 1984 and after 2014 can be found in Series II (Administrative Files).
Arrangement
This series is arranged chronologically.Newsletters (8 folders)1984-201411-8Series II. Administrative Files.71 Linear feetin two boxes1946-1959, 1978-2017
Scope and Contents
This series contains five sets of records maintained at various times over the course of PWCC's history. The first is a run of minutes of PWCC meetings, dating from 1946-1959. The second set includes the contents of binders maintained by the club's History Committee for years 1978-79 and 1979-80; these includes minutes, newsletters, member lists, competition results, and other documents for those years (see the more detailed content list at the folder level below). The third set includes minutes and newsletters from 1983-85, likely maintained by the Recording Secretary. The fourth set includes financial records (revenue, expenses) for 1978-88. The final set includes documents primarily from 2016-17 and relate to the activities of the Archive Committee then in place.
As can be seen from the above description, there are substantial gaps in coverage. There are no minutes or other administrative records for 1960-77 and from after 1985. The few newsletters in this series add some earlier years to those found in Series I (1984 and later), but there remain gaps.
Arrangement
This series is arranged by the sets of administrative records in the collection, which advance in rough chronological order, with sizable gaps in coverage.Minutes1946-194819Minutes1949110Minutes1950-1951111Minutes1952-1953112Minutes1954-1955113Minutes1956-19591141978-1979 Records, from Binder (5 folders)1978-1979115-19
Immediate Source of Acquisition
This binder was a gift from Paul Perkus.
Scope and Contents
Folders hold content taken from a 3-ring binder maintained by the club's historian for 1978-79, Dan Arthur: newsletters, meeting minutes, administrative correspondence, lists of general members, committees and committee members, event attendance counts, and slide and print competition grades.1979-1980 Records, from Binder (5 folders)1979-1980120-24
Scope and Contents
Folders hold content taken from a 3-ring binder, likely maintained by the chairperson of the History Committee for that year, Dan Arthur: membership and committee lists, newsletters, constitution (as adopted 1975 and amended through 1979), by-laws, meeting minutes, correspondence (including room reconstruction negotiations with the YMCA in connection with the Y's intent to have the PWCC share space with ceramics activities), YMCA photo competition & social activities (with a Christmas themed poem incorporating the names of all dues-paying members), member exhibitions (including a checklist of objects exhibited by PWCC members at the United Nations by invitation of the UN Staff Recreation Council), darkroom administration, score sheets for the black and white and color slides competitions, attendance records, and publicity flier.1983-1985 Records, from Binder (2 folders)1983-1984125-26
Scope and Contents
Folders hold content from binder likely maintained by Recording Secretary Lee Backer: newsletters, by-laws (as adopted 1980), and meeting minutes.Finances1978-198321Finances1983-198822Archive Committee Binder (2 folders)2014-201723-4
Scope and Contents
Folders hold content from a binder likely maintained by club archivist Myrna Changar: program and checklist/pricelist for PWCC member exhibition "A Sense of Wonder" at the Ryan/Chelsea-Clinton Community Health Center (2016); print-out lists from database of photographer works in PWCC archives (2016-17); Soho Photo Gallery floor plan and a few related documents in connection with planning for the 80th anniversary show (2016); Archive Committee newsletters; record of donation to PWCC archives of Myron Brenton materials (2017); agendas, correspondence, minutes, and other documents of the Archive Committee (2016-17); constitution (revised as of 2012); and other documents.Series III. Club Activities and Exhibitions1.84 Linear feetin two boxes plus flat files1947-2017
Scope and Contents
This series contains photographs, articles, and documents that showcase club activities and member achievements. The club activities range from photography excursions, club meetings and social outings, photography competitions, and PWCC exhibitions. Select member achievements are highlighted in newspaper articles, which are in very fragile condition. Some names found within the photo credits are confirmed members, while others are unconfirmed. There is also a folder on Otto Litzel, an honored club member, which also includes some background on the PWCC records. Significant exhibitions represented in this series are the Through Our Eyes exhibition of 2015 and the 2017 PWCC 80th anniversary show Eight Decades of Photography.
Arrangement
The series is arranged by subject matter.PWCC Photo Album Vol. III1984 June-November 525
Scope and Contents
Contains snapshots from club outings, meetings, and events. Album titled Vol. III, which is the only volume from this set in N-YHS's possession.Otto Litzel - Dinner, Speeches, Researchcirca 201226Select Member Achievements, PWCC Press1947-199027
Scope and Contents
Primarily holds original clippings either related to PWCC or that include photographs credited to PWCC members. Some of these materials were reproduced for PWCC's historical exhibition "Through Our Eyes," which are found in the following folders. Other than clippings, original documents include a Metropolitan Camera Club Council member directory (1976), a YMCA/PWCC publicity flyer (1960s?), and a copy of the YMCA's newsletter "West Side" for April 17, 1947, which carries a photograph by a PWCC (then Hypo Hounds) member and a mention of the club and darkroom."Salon Exhibitors of the Park West C.C." 1952-1957FF-9
Scope and Contents
7 original oversize sheets listing exhibitors from PWCC during 1952-57, with columns for name of the photographer/"maker", name of salon, title of print or slide exhibited, and any award received. Otto Litzel appears perhaps most frequently."Through Our Eyes." Introductory Boards2015FF-10
Scope and Contents
3 pasted-up boards with documents from the exhibition, including title, introduction, certificate reproductions, and prints of digital scans of "The Daydreamers" (1936) and "Field Trip" (1950s?)."Through Our Eyes." Reproductions of Clippings & Documents from the 1940s-1990s (6 folders)201528-13"Through Our Eyes." Photograph Prints (folder 1 of 2)2015214
Scope and Contents
7 black and white digital reproductions of gelatin silver prints, roughly 8 x 11 inches. M.D. Arnold "Little Girl with a Bonnet" (undated) (2 prints); Wally Arrington "Little Brother" (1968); Dan Arthur "Lady with a Necklace" (undated); Ann Jackson "New York Summer" (undated); Ray Long "Central Park Skyline" (1947); and Dan MacLaughlin "Sunnyside Yards" (1964)."Through Our Eyes." Photograph Prints (folder 2 of 2)2015FF-10
Scope and Contents
6 black and white digital reproductions of gelatin silver prints, roughly 16 x 11 inches. M.D. Arnold "Little Girl with a Bonnet" (undated) (2 prints); Wally Arrington "Little Brother" (1968); Ann Jackson "New York Summer" (undated); Ray Long "Central Park Skyline" (1947); and Dan MacLaughlin "Sunnyside Yards" (1964)."Through Our Eyes." Otto Litzel1970sFF-10
Scope and Contents
2 items: a dust jacket for Litzel's book "Darkroom Magic" and a thumbnail reproduction of "The Artist," photograph by Bill Berriell."Through Our Eyes." PWCC Members2015215
Scope and Contents
"Blue Nude" photograph series (5) by Evelyn Leif. Curriculum vita of Myron Brenton, Carolyn Bross, and Paul Knowles. Exhibition announcements and other ephemera concerning Dan Hines, Rosemary Peters and Yaqui Yamdrok."Eight Decades of Photography."1948-20174 1-3
Scope and Contents
Modern prints of photographs shown in the exhibition, identified by the wall they were mounted on; images of the backing of various photographs, showing award and other labels; Soho gallery layout used for the exhibition; publicity piece; and three "Archives Matter" newsletters from the PWCC Archives Committee leading up to the exhibition. Also holds an original 1948 certificate from the Metropolitan Camera Club Council recognizing The Hypo Hounds as a club member in good standing and a board with original award ribbons from the Council, circa 1950-60s."Eight Decades of Photography." MiscellaneousFF-11
Scope and Contents
Includes sheets of what appears to be wrapping paper, with exhibition images and themes. Also includes oversize reproductions of text and content related to the exhibition."Just One Day Old." Ryan Center Exhibit2016 March44
Scope and Contents
Print of digital reproduction of Harry Noah's photograph. Formerly in frame as presented at the Ryan Center exhibition; unframed during processing. Photocopy of exhibit label from backing is in folder.Series IV: Photography by Members8.24 Linear feetin two boxes plus flat files1940s-2000s
Scope and ContentsThis series contains original photographic work by club members. Most of these are individual prints, often mounted on backing material, ranging from the 1940s into at least the 1970s, though most are undated. The work of Harry Noah is especially well-represented in these photos. Many of the photographs and their backing are water damaged, as they were rescued from a flooded room.
In addition, the series includes photographs from an album maintained by the club. These photographs are by more recent members, and date from the 1990s into the 2000s. Most of these prints are black and white, though many are in color. Finally, the series includes slides by some recent members, principally Myron Brenton. Brenton's slides are of various New York City scenes, including scenes at Ground Zero after the 9/11 attacks on the World Trade Center.
A digitized slide show produced by the PWCC that includes some of these images and others can be seen here.
Arrangement
The series is arranged by format, with single photographs followed by those from the album and then slides. Within the single photographs, the arrangement is by photographer. Box 3 holds photos that are 8x11 inches or somewhat larger; flat files (FF) hold large mounted photos; and Box 4 holds photos of a size that fall between those two. Titles of work found on the print itself are noted in "quotation marks" in the container list; titles or descriptions provided by the processing archivist are noted in [brackets].Apple, Billundated46

Scope and Contents
Approximately 400 color slides. The subject most represented is Ground Zero in the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks on the World Trade Center. Other subjects include graffiti/wall art, construction sites, Coney Island, West Indian Day Parade, street fairs and festivals, the Brooklyn Bridge, and Central Park. Several sheets of slides are labeled "NYC Misc"; these appear to often fit into the above categories and are often of people and street scenes. and peopleSlides. Wallace, Mariecirca 2000s34
Scope and Contents
7 color slides of nature scenes and buildings.Slides. Various Photographerscirca 2000s35
Scope and Contents
32 slides (color and black and white) by various photographers. Identified photographers are Myron Brenton, Marilyn Fish-Glynn, Ruth Formanek, Myrna Harrison-Changar, Paul Knowles, Rosemary Peters, Helen B. Pine, Susan Sigrist, and Yaqui Yamdrok.
